title: Why do people say, "Bait out Fizz E, then fight him?" as counterplay advice?
body:
Any fizz player worth a damn won't press E unless it is a threatening spell. 

I'm sick to death of blind picking mid, enemy getting Fizz and ending the game at level 3.

How do you "Bait out" an ability against anyone with a brain?
Baiting something or something requires mistakes on the victims end. If he is wise enough to not get baited, what can be done?

EDIT: 
This is a legitimate cry for help, not a QQ thread.
It seems like a decent Fizz has the tools to outplay anything you throw at them.
It really feels like counterpicking is the only valid method of beating a **competent** player.

replies.body:
The idea is to bait it out with a minor spell (say if you're lux for example and getting a gank, use your E to try and get him to pole, so you still have Q) and then punish him for the usage.

Sadly it is about trying to force a mistake, and no it's not always easy but it is possible.

That's my point exactly. Why kind of moron would use  trickster on a Lux E when she has her Q up and you suspect a gank?

Even if he manages to fuck up royally and use his trickster prematurely, it only has a 3 second cooldown.

I have never found solid advice for laning against fizz other than, "Just counterpick"

>it only has a 3 second cooldown.

First point, it can't even get below 4 seconds because there isn't a way to get more the 50% CDR.

Second point, you're leaving it way too late to deal with a fizz then, in lane before 6, at best he maybe has it at a 10 second cooldown at Level 5 (assuming 15% CDR), this actually gives you time to punish it.

Otherwise the second it is down, Chain your CC and he will die.

4.4 sec cd. My bad. 

And as for your second point, we go back to our previous conversation,

>"Sadly it is about trying to force a mistake" 

How the fuck do they consider  a champion balanced when his only weakness relies on the player making a mistake?
Because why should a player be punished for playing perfectly?

"This champion has an aoe aura that instantly kills all players on the map if you press R 5 times a second."

It's perfectly balanced cause if he doesn't miss the R key he isn't making a mistake and shouldn't be punished.

Playing perfectly isn't very hard when there is minimal room for error.
And you just explained why that won't be a mechanic in the game.

So let's just switch it with..


"There's a champion who can burst out everyone in the game and can't be hit back"

It's okay because he perfectly timed his E.



And on the topic, why the fuck does his incredibly powerful  low cooldown "I literally can't be touched"  skill scale at 75% AP  AoE with a high slow, when most mages don't even get that scaling on a single target non cc ability.

>There's a champion who can burst out everyone in the game and can't be hit back

Which you know, doesn't exist.

Fizz isn't always invulnerable, you just clearly don't use the windows you get given.

Also it has a decent damage ratio because it's his safety measure and you get the AP ratio if you use it offensively instead of defensively.

Or you just use it to dodge cc (defensive) and then land on your opponent (offensive).

And you know, like every champ... If you have a window of vulnerability you play defensively and back off?
I'm not even bothering anymore, you're not willing to listen to reason, go play fizz and realize it's not as simple as you think.

yasuo is easy to fuck up on, and when you do, you usually get fucked up.

But if you play perfectly, you fuck them up and its complaints about op and easy because the skill is uncomprehendable.

No because playing Yasuo mediocrely (i'm not saying perfectly, i am saying basically average just not like a trash can) will actually make you do fairly decently.

Hell even the shit yasuo's can do flashy shit every now and then if the game goes long enough because yas.

And you think you have to be Faker to do okay on fizz?


He is much harder to misplay than Yasuo. When you can dodge all incoming damage every few seconds, you'd actually have to try to die.

Well how about this, prove your point, and pick Fizz and play him well, climb to Diamond+ because he clearly requires no skill from what you said.

Believe it or not, every death anyone has in league of legends is a mistake.
you could trick him and just use q over and over until he just instinctively uses e to dodge it, then trick him with an e

It's true Fizz is an incredibly menacing champion to have to lane against. But there are a few ways to beat him.

-Like you mentioned, counterpicking. Lissandra is personal favourite counter Fizz, she has really good lane phase poke which Fizz lacks, good disengage, enough cc to keep the slippery fuck still and can tomb herself to avoid Fizz's E+R and apply the ult damage. Kassadin and Leblanc are also decent matchups. Ahri and Zed are skill matchups but have just as much potential to fuck Fizz as he can to them.

-Barrier or Exhaust. Fizz is an all in champion, taking a summoner that renders that all in useless is very important. A well timed exhaust will cut his Pole and Fish damage down massively. Also a well timed barrier will negate lots of it.

-Just turret hug. If you're playing a champion that can absolutely not fight fizz under any circumstance at all, just stay far away from the back, and then some more. Any decent mid laner can pick up most cs that falls under turret. Fizz can't punish you much if he pushes you in, since he has no poke. If he wants to take advantage of the push by killing you, he has to go all in, under turret. And then it's all about individual player skill.

Out of all the champions in the game, Fizz could probably dive you the easiest.


Exhaust lets you live once. He sees the exhaust and backs out. Comes back in 10 seconds when his burst is back off cooldown.

His E has a very high mana cost and the cooldown isn't that short early game. 4.4seconds is with CDR, yet your complaints and the focus of this will be in the laning phase I assume. If he's taken CDR runes, then hes sacrificed MR. You have a lot of opportunity to try and force out his E with a low mana cost spell. If he uses his E aggressively it will push the lane. You can freeze against Fizz very easily in the early game as he wont be able to get any decent poke off and can certainly not dive you without eating through his entire mana/hp pool doing so. 

Freeze the wave and bait out his e with ANY CD's necessary. Then communicate to your jungler what is happening. Let him know the lane is frozen and Fizz is overextending. Communicate where any wards have been laid to make it easy for them.

It comes with experience and doesn't really have anything to do with the opponent having a brain. For example In a matchup of zed vs fizz, zed needs to practically all in aggressively to force fizz to use E before getting to low before zed using his ult. Or alternatively, initially ulting fizz, making him think he's about to go all in but instead continuing with a non ult reliant combo after baiting out the E, given fizz isn't full HP before the start of this scenario.

This is a case of just simply having to understand how Fizz works and functions as a champion in the mid lane. 

First part I would say is understand the range of his E, it's actually really short range and does have limitations. Knowing this will enable you to predict and dodge his E.

Secondly, watching for a glow in his trident, if it glows it'll cause additional magic damage dealt to you from his autos and abilities and for that reason some fizz's would use it before they engage. This is his W ability. 

Thirdly don't play someone with melee abilities unless they specifically have CC and burst damage to deal early on. The reason for this is because Fizz has a lot of mobility and damage but like every single champion he needs gold. If you play someone with a lot of poke potential you can effectively punish him for going for cs. If he wastes his E, this is an opportunity to punish him for a few seconds by throwing all your CC at him while he tries to make an escape. Even if it is without securing a kill Fizz will most likely be forced out of the lane which puts you a little ahead in exp and gold and that can make an incredible difference. 

Finally if you're laning against him build magic resist. It's really effective, if you're an assassin build maw, if you're a mage build abyssal scepter or athenes unholy grail or even Zhonyas hourglass. Don't stick to a copy/paste build. 

Yes Fizz himself is an extremely powerful champion when used correctly but he isn't unbeatable. CC is his prime weakness. You not dying also slows him down significantly. If you can't win then survive the laning phase. 
Hope this helps. :)

I've always had trouble with Fizz too. 

The general idea is to poke and deny him so that he'll be forced to go back. The reason that's more difficult than it sounds is that he's probably going to try trade back if you're careless. Never all in since his seastone trident + ignite do serious damage, especially when he's baited out one of your abilities and you weren't able to in return. Even if neither of you die he's probably going to out sustain you if he started corrupting potion. Try your best to not let him trade back.

If you're still having trouble, stop trying to win lane and figure out how to not lose lane. Play patiently and methodically and focus on surviving. If you've picked a decent teamfighting champion you can wait until the midgame and hope you are coordinated enough to beat him.

How do you not let him trade back, when he has two forms of gap close pre-6.

His Q range is that of most midlaner's auto attack range, so if you try to poke him with auto attacks he hard engages.
If you use a skill shot based spell on him, like all players, they can just walk to the side. Not very difficult when you have 'noclip' enabled.
If you click to target spell him and it has a missile, he will dodge it and hard engage. 
If the above click to target spell isn't very impactful, he will probably just engage with Q instead.

Past level 3 there isn't a lot you can do without him retaliating.

It really comes down to practice, match up and mentality.

Fizz has many ways to dodge and engage but he still has cooldowns and limited hp. There are windows in which you have to punish him. In those moments Fizz players are choosing between getting cs and taking damage and if you let him off scot free he's probably going to win the lane. It's just something you need to practice.
Its is kinda hard to bait it out  when its on 6 second cd
Less than that, 40% cdr is standard in season 6.
